awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Two Higgs are Better than One: Investigating Electroweak Symmetry Breaking at the LHC and Beyond with Real-Time Charged Particle Reconstruction
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a Career Award for the PI, a new assistant professor at Stanford U, to work on the ATLAS experiment at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN, a particle physics laboratory in Geneva, Switzerland.  The LHC machine and ATLAS, a large particle detector facility, were built as basic science tools using funds from NSF and other agencies around the world.  One of the primary objectives of the LHC at the time of construction was to find the Higgs Boson - the last particle in the historically successful "Standard Model" (SM) that accounts for so much of the existence of and forces between known particles forming the visible matter in the universe.  The search for the Higgs Boson was successful, so the discovery of the particles that lie within the realm of particle physics physics beyond the SM is now the goal.  This award is for work that could lead to such a discovery by filtering out events with two Higgs Bosons in them.

Principal Investigator Lauren Tompkins is starting a new experimental high energy physics group at Stanford University which will pursue a number of software algorithms that, working with a new real time hardware track reconstruction module (the FTK), will lead to a greatly enriched sample of Higgs pair candidates.  She will take primary roles within the collaboration to carry this out.  The group will support a vigorous and carefully planned broader impact program through courses for Stanford students and also outreach to local schools.  One of the principal aims is to increase enrollment in physics.  She will also mentor under-privileged students from Cal State institutions during summer break.  These students will obtain hands-on experience with both hardware and software.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The Large Hadron Collider was built to uncover the origin of electroweak symmetry breaking, and we have delivered on that task by discovering the Higgs boson. But the mere observation of the particle is not enough. The primary purpose of the LHC now and in its high luminosity future (HL-LHC, 2027-2037) is to measure the properties of the particle—how it interacts with other particles and itself. By making these measurements we will be able to understand if the Standard Model is dependent on the precise properties of the Higgs boson or if electroweak symmetry breaking is driven by a more complex theory. My work as a member of the ATLAS experiment has focused on probing the Higgs boson properties using b-quarks. These particles are the most strongly coupled particles to the Higgs boson yet their coupling is the most poorly measured, largely because the experimental signature is so challenging. Former graduate student Dr. Zihao Jiang and I made the ATLAS experiment’s first 13 TeV measurement of the vector boson fusion (VBF) production of Higgs boson decays to b-quarks.1 To improve the potential of future measurements, we developed a recurrent neural network-based b-quark identification algorithm which improved ATLAS’s ability to identify these critical particles, particularly at high momenta. We also measured the dominant background process, gluon splitting to b-quarks, which gave insight into the polarization of gluons produced in LHC collisions. For this body of work Dr. Jiang won the US ATLAS Outstanding Graduate Student award. Then I worked with a collaborator on extending this measurement to the full ATLAS dataset. We introduced several innovations, including utilizing adversarial neural networks to de-

correlate the Higgs boson signal strength estimator from the signal classifier, and mixing simulated and recorded data to measure the contribution of a key background process. With these improvements the sensitivity of the measurement increased nearly sixfold, far exceeding the factor of two improvement expected from a naive scaling of the size of the dataset in the previous measurement.


​​We also probed the electroweak symmetry breaking potential directly by searching for

di-Higgs production with decays to b-quarks and tau-leptons. This work was led by former postdoctoral scholar, Dr. Nikolina Ilic (now faculty at the University of Toronto), demonstrating the feasibility of a measurement which will be key to the HL-LHC. The HL-LHC will provide a factor of 20 more data than already available and make the definitive measurements of the electroweak symmetry breaking potential until a Higgs Factory or higher energy collider is built. 


We also explored connections between dark matter and electroweak symmetry breaking by doing a search for “dark sectors”, in which the dark matter is charged under one or

more new fundamental symmetries and couples feebly to the SM through a “portal.”  We investigated a dark Higgs portal and dark photon portal. The dark sector might solve the hierarchy problem: the fact that the observed Higgs boson needs such precise properties for the Standard Model to be self-consistent. Dr. Stanislava Sevova led the first search at

the LHC for dark Higgs production in which the dark Higgs decays to a pair of vector bosons. This analysis was the first search for any new physics in this signature, and employed new hadronic final state identification techniques. Dr. Sevova and then Dr. Rocky Garg also search for dark photons in the decays of Higgs bosons. This search set new limits on the decays of Higgs bosons to massive and massless dark photons. 


 


Last Modified: 05/30/2023
Modified by: Lauren Tompkins

With these improvements the sensitivity of the measurement increased nearly sixfold, far exceeding the factor of two improvement expected from a naive scaling of the size of the dataset in the previous measurement.



​​We also probed the electroweak symmetry breaking potential directly by searching for

This work was led by former postdoctoral scholar, Dr. Nikolina Ilic (now faculty at the University of Toronto), demonstrating the feasibility of a measurement which will be key to the HL-LHC. We also explored connections between dark matter and electroweak symmetry breaking by doing a search for "dark sectors", in which the dark matter is charged under one or

The dark sector might solve the hierarchy problem: the fact that the observed Higgs boson needs such precise properties for the Standard Model to be self-consistent. Dr. Stanislava Sevova led the first search at
the LHC for dark Higgs production in which the dark Higgs decays to a pair of vector bosons. This analysis was the first search for any new physics in this signature, and employed new hadronic final state identification techniques. Dr. Sevova and then Dr. Rocky Garg also search for dark photons in the decays of Higgs bosons. This search set new limits on the decays of Higgs bosons to massive and massless dark photons.
